data.text: Drop Bars on Touring Bikes: Are They Comfortable?

(edit: thanks everyone for the detailed responses. you're very helpful!) Why do touring bikes come stock with drop bars? Do people actually find them comfortable for long days on the bike? Drop bar lovers, if you're here, I'd love to hear what you like about them

data.text: Like almost everything else about cycling, bars are a matter of personal choice. i have had (and actually still do) both drops and flats in my approximate 60 years of cycling. My personal favorite for touring at this point in life are butterfly (aka touring) bars, which i think can combine the best features of drops and flats- multiple hand positions and both upright or more dropped riding positions. They don't work with all shifters, but both twist grips and thumb shifters work well on my bikes. Just another option for your consideration.

data.text: When riding on the road, a large percentage of your energy goes into overcoming the wind against your chest and upper body. Anything you can do to get down out of the wind resistance will make your ride lots more pleasant. Also, try this "experiment". Sit on a straight backed kitchen chair. Now, stand up. See how you automatically lean forward like you're bending over the drops... this allows you to bring your core muscles into play. The same ones you need to use for efficient pedaling. I took a 50 mile ride on the road , with a bunch of Rangers in Ft.Bragg. I had my road bike. They all rode "cruisers" mountain bikes, and Sears quality "street legal 10 speeds. They were all at least 10 years younger than me. Half of them dropped before 20 miles. The ones who did make it were exhausted. Oh, the drops also give you an opportunity to change hand position, which lets you "spread the load around".

data.text: Well, met many people who start by hating them then change their mind. The fact they have been popular for over a century must mean they fill a need. The straight I prefer on cycle paths where I need good control at low speed and the drops I prefer on longer road rides where can get low in high winds and descents, move the hands to different positions to avoid arm repetitive strain and puts the hands perfectly on brakes and gears. I think the body gets used to whatever type you have but if I had only one bike it would have dropped.
data.author: Tom Jones

data.text: Regardless of type of bar, the grips should not be so low that they cause a literal pain in the neck. Recently, I have been seeing frames that put the drops higher in relation to the saddle than the flat-bar grips on my mountain bikes, and I'm an old man who prioritizes comfort. It's strange to see, but there's nothing wrong with it. Drop-bar bikes are made for keeping the hands below the shoulders for efficient weight bearing. Flat bars are made to keep the hands wide and out in front for steering control in difficult terrain and for preventing o-t-b. As others have mentioned, many tourers are using bars that are somewhere in between.

data.text: I have 3 bikes, a touring bike, road bike and gravel bike. All have drop bars but every single one has a different geometry. A dropbar isnt the only deciding factor of placing the body into an aggressive position, it has much more to do with frame size, stem length, stem angle and risers and all of that is relevant to your body. I choose the dropbar because of the multiple hand options. Also if you bring your arms forward they will most likely align naturally into the most common hand placement of a dropbar which are the hoods. I try to keep the width of the handlebar similar to the shoulder which keeps my arms in a more natural position. But this is relevant to me. I do realize that with a mtb grometry especially a wider flat handlebar is necessary to provide leversge on account of a longer fork and more technical terrain.

Into a head wind being on the drops means you are more aerodynamic etc. However its like anything else use what suits you. People get too hung up on this or that bit of kit. I used to Audax on a drop bar ,clipped in, 18 speed road bike. I regularly shared the road with a chap 30 years my senior who rode flat bars complete with posy of flowers and plimsolls on flat pedals. 2,3 or 4 hundred kms he always finished with a smile on his face. data.author: Dave Oakes

data.text: I ride all sorts of bars on my bikes including drop, flat and alt. Don't be afraid to fit drop bars with short and/or angled stems to shorten reach and raise height for long distance comfort - really works for me - especially as I get a bit older. If you are used to upright bikes then outfit your drop bars in a similar fashion or you'll just be miserably uncomfy - you can always experiment with longer and lower reach once you get the hang of it. If you are not used to drop bars be aware that they steer from the hip and by subtle leaning of the head and then the shoulders more than by actually turning the bars - except at much slower speeds. It can take a bit of getting used to but the bike sure does flow effortlessly.
data.author: Frith Wood
